items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The ability of new chelate ligands, benzoxazol-5-yl-alanine derivatives substituted in position 2 by heteroaromatic substituent, to form complexes with selected metal ions in acetonitrile are studied by means of absorption and steady-state and time-resolved fluorescence spectroscopy. Among the ligands studied, only azaaromatic derivatives form stable complexes with transition metal ions in the ground state. Their absorption bands are bathochromically shifted enabling to use those ligands as ratiometric sensors. The fluorescence of each ligand is quenched by metal ions, however, in the presence of Cd(II) and Zn(II) ions a new red shifted emission band is observed.</jats:p>
title: Fluorescent chemosensors for metal ions based on 3-(2-benzoxazol-5-yl)alanine skeleton
3-[2-(Boronophenyl)benzoxazol-5-yl]alanine derivatives as fluorescent monosaccharide sensors

items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The influence of peptide sequence and Leu chirality in linear and cyclic peptides containing 3-[2-(9-anthryl)benzoxazol-5-yl]alanine on interaction with β-cyclodextrin were studied using fluorescence and NMR spectroscopy. The analysis of enthalpy-entropy compensation effect (α=1.05±0.02 and TΔS00=15.1±0.5 kJ mol−1) indicates that the entropic contribution connected with the solvent reorganization is the major factor governing the peptides-β-cyclodextrin complexation. Moreover, spatial orientation of guest-host molecule depends more than association constant on Leu residue configuration. However, the cyclization of the peptide chain substantially decrease the association constant with β-CD. An analysis of 2D NMR spectra reveals that inclusion complex is formed by penetration of cyclodextrin cavity from wider and narrow rims by anthryl group in the case of Box(Ant)-SPKL or anthryl and Leu residues for Box(Ant)-SPK(D)L analogue.</jats:p>
title: Influence of amino acid sequence on the interaction of short peptides containing 3-[2-(9-anthryl)benzoxazol-5-yl]-alanine with β-cyclodextrin

items.abstract: <jats:p>In the present study 32 species of lichens were found. The most numerous were crustose lichens. which are typical of rocks. The follwing species which are known to occur rarely in Poland were identified: <i>Acarospora</i> cf. <i>umbibilicata</i> and <i>Lecidella</i> cf. <i>carpathica</i>. Two species of the genus <i>Lepraria</i> were also noted; among them <i>Lepraria caesioalba</i> had not been reported previously from Poland. The non-uniform distribution of lichens in the castle area, mainly the presence of "lichen deserts" was. probably associated with human activities. The most frequent occurring lichens were synanthropic, easily spreading species, e.g. <i>Caloplaca citrina, Lecanora albescens</i> and <i>L. dispersa</i>.</jats:p>
title: The lichen flora of the Malbork Castle (N. Polami)
Photobiont flexibility in the lichen Protoparmeliopsis muralis as revealed by ITS rDNA analyses
A preliminary study on the phylogeny of the genus Melanelia using nuclear large subunit ribosomal DNA sequences.

items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The phylogeny of the <jats:italic>Micarea prasina</jats:italic> group was investigated using mitochondrial small subunit ribosomal DNA sequences from 14 taxa representing this group, four other members of the genus <jats:italic>Micarea</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>Psilolechia lucida</jats:italic> as an outgroup. A total of 31 new mtSSU rDNA sequences were generated, including 10 from the <jats:italic>M. micrococca</jats:italic> complex. Bayesian, maximum parsimony (MP) and maximum likelihood (ML) methods were used to analyse the data. The results show that <jats:italic>M. micrococca</jats:italic> is not monophyletic and forms three strongly supported lineages: 1) <jats:italic>M. micrococca</jats:italic> s. str., 2) <jats:italic>M. byssacea</jats:italic> (Th. Fr.) Czarnota, Guzow-Krzemińska &amp; Coppins comb. nov., and 3) a putative taxon that requires further studies. <jats:italic>Micarea viridileprosa</jats:italic> is a sister species to <jats:italic>M. micrococca</jats:italic> s. str. and the recently described <jats:italic>M. nowakii</jats:italic> is a sister species to <jats:italic>M. prasina</jats:italic> s. str. The placement of <jats:italic>M. tomentosa</jats:italic> within the <jats:italic>M. prasina</jats:italic> group is confirmed. <jats:italic>Micarea hedlundii</jats:italic> appears to be more closely related to the <jats:italic>M. micrococca</jats:italic> complex than <jats:italic>M. prasina</jats:italic> s. str. Descriptions, illustrations, taxonomic remarks, distribution and habitat data for <jats:italic>M. micrococca</jats:italic> s. str. and <jats:italic>M. byssacea</jats:italic> are provided. A lectotype for <jats:italic>Biatora byssacea</jats:italic> Hampe non Zwackh and a neotype for <jats:italic>Catillaria prasina</jats:italic> β [var.] <jats:italic>byssacea</jats:italic> are selected.</jats:p>
title: A phylogenetic study of the  Micarea prasina group shows that  Micarea micrococca includes three distinct lineages

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
            <jats:p>
               <jats:italic>Bacidina flavoleprosa</jats:italic> is described as a new species from the Czech Republic. Its position within the genus is supported by phylogenetic inferences of ITS rDNA sequences from its holotype and many other representatives of <jats:italic>Bacidia</jats:italic> s. lat., including newly sequenced <jats:italic>Bacidina sulphurella</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>B. adastra</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>B. neosquamulosa,</jats:italic> as well as additional sequences of <jats:italic>B. arnoldiana</jats:italic>. ITS data also support the recent delimitation of <jats:italic>B. arnoldiana</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>B. sulphurella</jats:italic> based on the shape of conidia and ecological preferences.</jats:p>
title: ITS rDNA data confirm a delimitation of Bacidina arnoldiana and B. sulphurella and support a description of a new species within the genus Bacidina
